New York University Archives
Arthur Blum Student Lab Book
Blum, Arthur A.
MC.338
.25 Linear Feet in one half manuscript box
1901-1924 Arthur A. Blum was a student at New York University's College of Dentistry in the 1920s. This collection consists of his 1922 physiology lab notebook and health publications from the same period. Materials are in English. Materials are stored offsite, and advance notice is required for use. Please request materials at least two business days prior to your research visit to coordinate access.
Scope and Contents
This collection consists of a 1922 Physiology Lab textbook, entitled "Directions for Classwork in Experimental Physiology - Stein." It was used by Arthur A. Blum, a student at the New York College of Dentistry in 1924. The book has extensive manuscript diagrams, annotations and marginalia, along with tipped in kymograph readings. A few items of ephemera were laid in behind the front cover. These include a 1921 Bulletin from the NYC Deparment of Health, a Syllabus of Bacteriology, and several more kymograph readings.
Arrangement
Materials are arranged in original order.
Biographical / Historical
Arthur A. Blum was a student at New York University's College of Dentistry in the 1920s.
Conditions Governing Access
Material pertaining to individual student records may be restricted in accordance with the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act (FERPA). Please contact the Archives with specific questions regarding access to such records.
Conditions Governing Use
Any rights (including copyright and related rights to publicity and privacy) held by the creator are maintained by New York University. Permission to publish or reproduce materials in this collection must be secured from New York University Archives, (212) 998-2646, university-archives@nyu.edu.
Immediate Source of Acquisition
Gift of Carolyn Trietsch in 2014.
Preferred Citation
Identification of item, date (if known); Arthur Blum Student Lab Book; MC 338; box number; folder number; New York University Archives, New York University Libraries.
Processing Information
Materials were placed in an acid-free box.
